PostTitle: Run away, don't walk!
Pros: Staff benefits, the programs are very good however IT support is atrocious. There is a procedure for absolutely everything so you aren't left wondering how to do things in the branch network.
Cons: Sell, sell, sell! Everything at CBA is about selling. Don't believe the reports that  things have changed and performance is based on customer service. They may have on paper but sales numbers are still tracked.

PostTitle: Great to start your career in banking; not so great to stay for more than a few years
Pros:
- Great work culture
- Amazing colleagues
- good career progress
Cons:
- hard to get leave approved
- no full-time opportunities
- no staff benefits of real value

PostTitle: A job that give you a salary to put bread on the table for the family and pay rent/mortgage.
Pros:
Career break for max 2 years or more depends on each person circumstances - then come back to your own role or share role.
Free shares annually.
I enjoyed Roster Day Off monthly.
Cons:
Depends  on each individual and very result driven.
some only last after 3 months while others can work well and last longer.
sometimes very stressful when you have young family.

PostTitle: I love working in CBA, I have an opportunity to positively impact our customers everyday.
Pros: Work life balance is great, many opportunities for development and progression, very diverse & open mindset.
Cons: Huge team which makes change slow & sometimes not timely.

PostTitle: Great company that looks after it's staff and it is heading in the right direction by putting stronger focus on the customer.
Pros: Work life balance. Management and leadership genuinely care about your development, health, personal wellbeing and providing opportunity to for career progression.
Cons: A lot of organisational change and the inherent challenges associated with this.

PostTitle: I had a great experience in working for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and I would recommend it to anyone.
Pros:
Good camaraderie and a close knit team
Excellent software system
The organisation is run extremely well generally speaking 
Supportive leadership
Great uniform
Cons:
After 2009 the staff cuts, and the cutting of casual workers, were challenging things to endure for the remaining staff and put a lot of stress of management to get figures and work done with less staff.

The wages, although better than award is not necessarily very high.

PostTitle: I highly recommend working for the CBA, they acknowledge when they have not got things right, they encourage and support personal development, a positive workplace environment.
Pros: The CBA is big on work/life balance and whenever possible offer flexibility in the workplace. They are also big on 'the customer experience' and encourage continuous improvement for the organisation as a whole and welcome input from staff...also to question 'why am I doing this, is there a better way?' Actively support reward and recognition.
Cons:
As with all big corporations, communication can be challenging, not all depts are delivered the same or differing interpretation of information.
Also the nature of the industry, many customers have unrealistic expectations and these matters can get quite tense , but training is provided to handle these situations and safety is always paramount and so are encouraged to refer any delicate matters to a senior staff management.

PostTitle: Overall a good experience , but a lot to improve from management
Pros: Good hours, good life/work balance
Cons: Not proper training provided all the time, shortage in staff, too many products and knowledge required that not allows you to specialise in few thinks

PostTitle: You'll have your good days and bad days,
Pros: The staff discounts, the career development can expand to different areas, making friends, work/life balance for many.
Cons: LIke many jobs theres pros and cons. The old school mentality will make your job challenging trying to bring in new improvements, sometimes you'll feel unrewarded for being a hard worker & at times if you consider to progress into a leader its mostly who you know than what you know so that will also be a challenge. Also, some management make big deals over little things but turn their backs on better things to worry about.

PostTitle: Very political- play smart, understand the rules but stick to your principles
Pros: Great talent, wonderful teams. Fun projects. Inspiring hard working design culture, lots to learn and share. Big beast of a company with an exciting learning curve, but as someone else has said - don’t stay here too long.
Cons:
Very competitive, too much ego, poor ethics.
Loyalty is not rewarded. Very hierarchical which can impact your work. There is a lack of accountability and opportunities to grow. Set boundaries and define a clear personal timeline when working here, otherwise you can easily stop evolving. Your “fit” will ultimately determine your success or failure. Core values ineffective, many don’t live them. Too much ego which gets in the way of making things happen.

PostTitle: Great opportunity to work for a leading organisation
Pros: Flexibility and the technology that enables you to meet remotely. The office is set up for proper agile work and there is true activity based working. New Darling Square office is very nice. You also get some good employee banking benefits.
Cons: Large company with many layers of bureaucracy. There are areas where engagement scores are very low and attrition is high and it doesn't seem to really register with the group executives.  Obviously there's ethical practises being raised through royal commission as well.

PostTitle: Had lots of success but you need to understand and follow protocol to progress
Pros: Great systems, good innovation . Great opportunity for female managers wanting to climb the corporate ladder
Cons: Average pay, you hope for a bonus that is based on too many uncontrollables. Lacks transparency. Salary growth non existent

PostTitle: Had the opportunity to work on multiple critical projects that strengthened my skills and experience.
Pros:
Interesting projects
Highly motivated teams
Cons: Change in ways of working with each change of higher management, without understanding what went right or wrong with the current process.

PostTitle: Might be back one day
Pros:
Great career longevity 
Clear vision and values 
Clear expectations at awesome leadership teams 
Awesome reward and recognition
Cons: Very Sydney centric organisation - a lot of work still to be done to promote role mobility vs people mobility

PostTitle: Great experience for first serious job, plenty  of opportunity for progress and movement.
Pros:
Please note, I worked there many years ago.
No issues with pay or super and good staff bonuses- ie shares .. Great environment to work in for a large corporation
Cons:
Too much focus on sales- good for profit but bad for customer relations.
Could focus on employing more older staff members

PostTitle: Impactful and flexible work with great team cultures
Pros: The culture within the teams. From funny banter to ping pong to Hearthstone each team I spent time in offered great experiences. I take full advantage of the work/life balance offered here as well to support my volunteering commitments with full backing from managers. If you want to make a difference both at work and within your community this is definitely a place you want to be. The managers have also been exceptional.
Cons: While rare a hierarchy exists in some areas which can impact your work. Although PA's do a great job managing this and it doesn't apply to analytical areas I've been to.

PostTitle: Don't stay longer than you need to
Pros: Fantastic peers, training, learning opportunities, experimental, innovative. They also attract a lot of brilliant talent (but fail at the senior management level).
Cons: Unfortunately, managers at almost every level are incompetent, lack empathy, take the credit for what their team members do and/or just have their own agendas. The bank also doesn't seem to hire managers who possess the same skills as their teams so they can't be mentors or manage teams well. They also don't focus on improving people and culture and then wonder why the survey results are low and blame it all on the poor workers.

PostTitle: Everything at CBA just works.
Pros: Commonwealth Bank is one of the best resourced companies I've ever worked for. The Process, Procedures, and Technology enable me to do my job and deliver the best outcomes for my customers. This combined with a supportive management structure and a truly positive culture means that I'll be working at CBA until I retire.
Cons: There arn't many negatives working here at CBA
Location: Bondi Junction, New South Wales, Australia

PostTitle: Wonderful place to work.  Wish I could return.
Pros: Very understanding to life changes.  I was with the Commonwealth Bank before I was married to when I started a family.  They were always helpful in getting me the right position close to home to help out with my needs.  I have made wonderful friends who I still are in contact with today!
Cons: Sales Targets are high, but they keep you working hard and make for a great day when that bonus is handed to you.

PostTitle: Great career learning and opportunity, recommend to any young starter
Pros: The company provide great trainings and opportunities are limitless if you are good at your job. The company accomodate the staffs often if they moved to another area or city.
Cons: It has been quite a journey my 7 years with CBA. I wouldn't be who I am today if it wasn't for the experience and learning CBA provided. but that's most jobs. Depends on where you are located the sales pressure can be overwhelming .

PostTitle: Ruthless.
Pros: Some staff discounts for insurance products, but they don't treat staff any better than any other customer when you need to make a claim. And if you have a banking dispute they will dare you to go to the ombudsman.
Cons:
Loyalty is not rewarded. 
Poor commitment to training - they prefer to have other people pay for it and then hire it in. 
If you are a specialist in a particular area, they don't retrain you when they change technology, they just show you the door.
"Activity based working" (don't have your own desk) and poor building design leads to high transmission rates for airborne illnesses, and noise transmission makes it difficult to engage in "deep work" where you need uninterrupted concentration to complete complex or creative tasks.

PostTitle: Largest, yet still a traditional bank at risk of disruptive innovation
Pros: Similar to other large organizations and consistent with 21st century business model, CBA provides great opportunities for women and diverse background candidates for career advancement.
Cons:
Depending on business units and work environments (not necessarily reflective of the entire organization), my observations of the BU I worked for:
- Cost is still a major driver to people management, often at the expense of talented employees
- Lack of job design
- Traditional rather than transformation/collaborative leaders 
- Transactional rather than relational employee-employer relationship
- Rigid process/policies/procedures, internal systems with pre-existing issues/bugs and lack of reliable tools for analytics in lending space are primary issues that impedes speed to market 
- Requires improved management of change

PostTitle: Not what you would expect from a multi billion dollar company
Pros: Some of the staff are friendly and caring but overall the culture is terrible. There is a lack of accountability. Lots of talk and very little action.
Cons: Management have a terrible "metric" culture in which they obsess over data and stats but fail to understand the purpose behind the data or stats. Management show little respect to frontline staff.

PostTitle: Great culture.  I've worked for CBA twice and both times it was great.  The culture is really mature and people are easy to get on with
Pros:
Good team 
Good facilities 
Wifi worked everywhere
Email and access all working from day one 
Friendly culture
Cons: Hot desking not good.  No permanent desk meant you couldn't sit with team.  Had to keep things in locker.  Had to clean desk everyday before using it

PostTitle: Large organisation with opportunities, comes with the usual pros and cons
Pros: Modern office spaces, embraces flexible working, a large organisation within which there are numerous development/progression opportunities
Cons: As with all organisations, it really depends on which area you're in and what sort of people make up your team/stakeholders as to what experience you will have.

PostTitle: CBA is that one company that you'll never think of leaving.
Pros: They invest resources to ensure that they give the best conditions to their staff. They look after their people and encourage professional growth. They look after your personal well-being and provide maximum level of support regardless of your rank!
Cons: As with any large companies, risk and compliance are two top things that we always need to be careful about. This sometimes leads to slow development pace, however, I'd say this is justifiable.

PostTitle: I can confidently and proudly say that my peers and I all work to the values of integrity, collaboration, service, excellence and accountability on a daily basis, and we achieve the goals we set with the support of our managers and other leaders.
Pros: As a Commonwealth Bank employee, I feel very supported both from within the branch and from the leaders above us. There is so much opportunity to grow and learn, and I have felt that my managers have backed me 100% when I needed it. The pay is very attractive, especially if KPIs are met, and I especially love the values based drive behind those KPIs.
Cons: The work life balance piece can be difficult, especially now that I am expecting a family and knowing that my role requires a full time commitment. That being said, the Commonwealth Bank is exceptional at being as flexible as possible in finding more flexible arrangements for staff.

PostTitle: Supported in every position, a real opportunity for a great career - especially for the career focused individual.
Pros: If you are very career focused than you will be greatly supported in regards to your development and career progression with a seemingly endless list of opportunities. Management are also very supportive of an actual work-life balance with the Bank providing great options for those requiring temporary or permanent relief in regards to working outside of the normal 9 to 5.
Cons: Changes made on a very regular basis - It's obviously a requirement in order to remain competitive although constant updates (and regulatory amendments) have made the job challenging yet still rewarding.

PostTitle: A varied and exciting place to work
Pros: Career/professional development is seen as a priority and you are always encouraged to be proactive. There is great communication within your business unit, management are approachable.
Cons: There is a degree of inflexibility when it comes to moving outside your role within certain business units but this is mostly down to your managers. There is a lot of productivity oversight which does feel like micromanaging at moments - again depending on where you sit within the business

PostTitle: A great place to work and I would and have highly recommended to my friends and colleagues.
Pros: Great leadership; great opportunities for development;  values and culture are meaningful and everyone lives and breathes them; working with really good people.
Cons: Not too many other than the standard issues you face in any corporate ... sometimes it can take a little long to get responses from other parties across the organisation.

PostTitle: Met great people, managed home and work life very well and learnt to surround myself with great people leaders.
Pros: The good thing is its Work life balance.
Cons: The challenge is  it needs more great people leaders. Often seen those plodding along eventually manage or miss manage people.

PostTitle: Great at the start, great technology , which you can see will replace alot of workers in the future.  CBA and all the banks are only worried about their bottom line in the end. If your a minion then this job is for you, If not theres other bigger and bett
Pros: Stable Job , secure, opportunity to advance if you follow the system, good culture within the bank
Cons: High expectations, Look at every way to add extra work to to your plate in order to minimise your bonus potential,  even though they try to sell you that they are trying to help you.  Theres a lot of sheep mentality, the want you to express your concerns and opinions to make it a better working place, but when you do your frowned up.  They talk about great work life balance, there is no work life balance in a bank, its all about the numbers. Introducing more systems to make things easier , which in reality only makes things more complicated, more reporting , contributing to slower turn around time, and having to pretend that everything is now better

PostTitle: With a focus on the customer and also a very caring attitude about their people, The Commonwealth Bank was overall good to work for.
Pros: It was always good when we where treated as professional, adult, skilled workers, if methods are found that services customers better, they where generally embraced and awarded. As staff, a focus was on and how we are feeling etc as individuals, made me feel good.
Cons: I believe the bank needs to be overall more focused on what customers want and need, less focused on who does what and how many, in a demanding environment its service that counts.

PostTitle: A wonderful place to work with great opportuniy for those that work hard
Pros:
Great training, development and career opportunities 
Wonderful people and great teams
Excellent flexible working options and some wonderful initiatives happening around diversity and inclusion
Cons: It's a big business, so can be difficult to navigate through. All in all though, I feel the business stays remarkably agile given it's scale

PostTitle: Good company to work for if you live by sales and service.
Pros: Great career development opportunities. Work/life balance is good. Continually challenged and rewarded for hard work. Bonus potential is a great way CBA rewards their staff.
Cons: Depending on what sort of manager you work for your job can be either amazing or terrible. More should be done in selecting the leaders at CBA to ensure that there is a great staff moral and support in all levels of the group. Sales targets and referral targets from time to time can be quite challenging especially given that they are the same all year round given that it may be harder to make targets around Christmas/New Years and other seasonal periods.

PostTitle: Great opportunities to deliver significant change for staff and customers.
Pros: Great bunch of dedicated people who try every day to do excellent work while supporting colleagues and front line teams. The work is never dull and there are many challenges but it is great to part of such a large organisation.
Cons: The organisation and management team is constantly changing and adapting to a very competitive environment and it is hard to deliver lasting changes which ensure we have the edge. Flexibility and being creative helps meet these challenges.

PostTitle: Would never ever work at another bank , our systems / processes / technology / innovation / products absolutely surpass what any other financial institution in Australia can provide!!
Pros: THE best systems out of all the banks by a mile, I have worked at other banks which are manual paper based processes, everything is paperless and electronic at CBA
Cons: None currently, depends greatly on which department you are in

PostTitle: Don't come for the money, but do come for the work environment!
Pros:
- Supportive management teams
- Generally great people within the business that you like coming to work with. Collegiate environment despite the size of the business
- Lots of career progression opportunities and the business is supportive of staff looking to undertake industry accreditations or other professional courses/designations. Often will provide financial support if relevant to role.
- Flexible working arrangements for those that need them
- CBA staff benefits like fee free/lower fee accounts, discounts on loans and credit cards plus other benefits
- Workplace is state of the art in a new building
Cons:
- As with most large organisations there can be a lot of red tape and delays when trying to progress with ideas or projects
- Personally, not a fan of activity based working (we have the Google-style workplace with no fixed seating) as it's not suitable for my role and team. However, many will view this as a positive aspect
- Although we use the latest hardware, some standard business-wide software is outdated and makes certain tasks harder than they should be

PostTitle: The position I work and the department is good to work for as management listens to what you have to say even if they can't act upon it
Pros:
Interaction with management
Opportunity to progress you career
Ability to expand your skill set
Cons: Not being able to always act on suggestion provided

PostTitle: Many opportunities to work, grow and learn within a well recognised and respected company.
Pros: Great training and support. CBA really look after their employees and recognise hard work and people who do well. The company really puts the customer at the centre of everything we do so we know we are working to help people not just for a company to make money.
Cons: Dealing with targets and busy days when staff were cut short.

PostTitle: Opportunities abound but before of politics
Pros: Big company so there's opportunity to move to different roles.  People are generally friendly. Depending on teams, one can get pretty good exposures to a range of work requirements
Cons: A staff can be faced with disconnect between senior and middle management  , hence working in such teams can be challenging from a priority and delivery perspective .

JobTitle: Specialist In Branch And School Banking
PostTitle: A company with financial benifet for personal.banking needs while being a secure 4 star rated bank.

and never replaced staff with casual help when required as cut staff down and will continue

PostTitle: I treated all work colleagues regardless of position or title with respect, compassion and justice similarly for customers and as result I received delightful rewards and gained some wonderful insights into leadership roles and more importantly what makes
Pros:
I was always recognised for my work efforts and received delightful rewards.
We had the opportunity to put forward suggestions for change and a team would review and implement them. 
I was able to enjoy the opportunities of career development starting in a Customer Service Inbound Call Centre and moving onto a Change Management Analyst role and then to a Team Leader/Mamager role of various teams.

Change Management and motivating employees to continue to provide excellent customer service during a stressful and emotional period - preparation to close our Melbourne office. 
Being enthusiastic and self-disciplined even when I no longer had a role.

PostTitle: Overall the job is ok, if you like sales and customer service you will enjoy the job. the only thing I didn't like is the pressure they put on you if the company isn't hitting sales targets and they only offer part time which is the downside.
Pros: If you enjoy customer service and dealing with customers face to face then you will enjoy the role. you can get some nice perks working for CBA and could potentially get bonues if your branch hits target.
Cons: There is a lot of pressure on sales so if you're not very confident with sales then I wouldn't recommend this role. CBA is very sales orientated and if you don't hit your target then you will lose out on your bonus. Also it's they make it hard to get full time work in a branch and mainly offer part time also To be honest the pay isn't the best

PostTitle: Interesting place which provides you the flexibility so you can work and what you are interested in.
Pros:
Working from home one day a week.
Flexible work arrangement.
Big budgets for building new capabilities.
Cons:
You never get your entire bonus.
Rating your team members in PFR. There is hardly any recognition for a superior team. Only for superior individuals.
Location: Sydney CBD, New South Wales, Australia

PostTitle: An evolving, ever changing, challenging and fun workplace all in one!
Pros: Working environment and team atmosphere are great! It's a very diverse and inclusive workplace, and all of our colleagues are genuine, friendly and a lot of fun. The support factor is also very much there; the management are approachable and considerate, and will always do their best to fight for the outcome that's best for you. On top of this there are plenty of coaching and training sessions to ensure you're constantly improving and performing within your role. There are lots of employee benefits and discounts, as well as reward and recognition schemes to work towards.
Cons: There's a lot of information/policies/procedures to retain and things are constantly changing, and I mean constantly! You always have to be on your toes, in particular from a risk and compliance perspective. There are many KPI's to meet and it's a very structured environment; you need to be doing what your schedule says you should be doing at the time it says you should be doing it to avoid causing a domino effect for other areas of the business. It can be a very draining workplace if you are unable to find ways to manage your time/workload efficiently.

PostTitle: Experience of working with Pioneer and digital innovations.
Pros: Good work-life balance, open people and you will heard most of the times. People will be taken care for food and travel if they are late at work and overtime money if any.
Cons: Sometimes you will have to be hard on people to understand importance of the situation. Not my fault attitude of some vendor resources does not help project much.

PostTitle: Good life balance
Pros:
Working at CBA has been a great experience as well as a learning one at the same time. Being my first job in the banking sector it thought me a lot, with it's own highs n lows I've slowly and steadily reached to this position (credit officer) where I am today. Having been worked for 7 years I gained a lot of knowledge in different areas of credit, and also got the opportunity to be a part of some of the big projects like the collateral management. 
The friendly environment and good work ethics motivated us to give our best at all times, wherein also enabling us to enjoy more family time
Cons: Not enough oppurtunities to grow as they move there business to interstate

PostTitle: It was a great experience, learnt quite a few useful skills, had fun working with colleagues, however I didn't agree with the corporation incentives and pressure from managers.
Pros: Training before commencing work as well as ongoing training is very useful and helps to remain up to date with products and procedures, making it easy to maintain job readiness. Salary was good and day to day work didn't get repetitive because of all the different clients and tasks that would fill in the days. Having good work colleagues was something that made the difference between the job being enjoyable as opposed to boring.
Cons: The bank uses a target/reward system to encourage employees to work more efficiently. However, I found that this 'target' system, where each employee was set a target number and to achieve their assigned target, they would need to be getting referrals or setting up services for clients. Products that held numerical rewards for points included new accounts, loans, credit cards, etc. I found this system was good in the sense it prompted employees to continually inform customers of new deals or products on offer, however, it also culminated in a lot of pressure to maintain weekly targets and essentially I felt it made a lot of employees treat customers like numbers, which defeats the focus Commonwealth Bank pushes so hard for, being number one in customer service. So I found the managers to be challenging because they only seemed to be interested in how much money or equity employees had made for the bank each day.

PostTitle: Life changing
Pros: Being able to assist with fulfilling goals of clients and helping them achieve financially. Also ensuring they are adequately protected for almost any circumstance and watching them leave with a smile on their face after being able to assist with any queries they may have!
Cons: Sometimes targets can be stressful and there is such a vast amount to learn whether it be processes, products and just how to deal with certain situations.

PostTitle: I would go back again if there is an opportunity open.
Pros: Exposure of diversed range of clients; also gained knowledge on different financial products; which helped with my current role as an accountant
Cons: There are always some challenging customers, but helped me to acquire problem solving skills, resolving complaints or conflicts.

PostTitle: Great training system and good career development, solid professional experiences.
Pros: Top 500 company, their training is excellent. Career development within the company is great, you have various opportunities.
Cons: Workload is way above average, at the other hand pay is just average. Management somehow is case by case scenario, you will see some good leaders while at the same time some not as good.

PostTitle: If you want the ultimate experience in banking. This is it!
Pros: Great work environment. Great run business. Great training. Great team morale. Awesome place to work
Cons: The sales! I'm not a natural born seller. Picking up clues or even initiating sales was total foreign to me despite working in retail for 20 years
Location: Coffs Harbour, New South Wales, Australia

PostTitle: Enjoyed the bank during the 1980 to 1991. They were the good old days.  Lifelong friendships were made with people I worked with.
Pros: Was fortunate to have a housing loan at 4 percent, when everyone else housing loans were 17%.  RDO every 3 weeks were a bonus.
Cons: Banking changed in the late 1990's. It became a sell/sell industry.  The prestige of working for the bank disappeared, and you became a sales person. Definitely have to question some of the people who were promoted. Quiet achievers were always overlooked.  Footballers were always promoted due to status for the bank. Very disappointing going into a bank now and the branch manager now is mid 20's usually a graduate from University.  They have no idea what banking is about.

PostTitle: Learning about state of the art technology with my CBA family
Pros: CBA is a very big family to me! Everyone looks after each other re work or outside of work. CBA staff and management do really care about their employees and colleagues. Theres amazing rewards and incentives in place! Great $$ 's in bonus' also.
Cons: Helping our customers accept and use the different options of banking these days. Eg: Self Service Options. Staff are still around and we will always be there to help our customers, however some customers perspective is "if i use that machine it puts you out of a job"  It in fact makes our job easier if they use those options. Educating our customers is the hardest part. The technology is amazing and is there to make the lives of our staff and community easier, quicker and more convenient. Gone are the days of 9.30-4 bank hours! Gone are the days of endless teller queue's, now to change the mindset!

PostTitle: Rewarding and always full of action.
Pros: The cba had excellent computer systems , very easy to navigate. The general processing software was state of the art! Enjoyed interacting with clients and staff.
Cons: Work days were always full of different client issues and depending on the demographics at times targets were unachievable.

PostTitle: An organisation where you can gain experience across many different areas but its up to you to manage your Career.
Pros: Great people, smart and very skilled at what they do. Very innovative work space and an organisation that is right at the top of its game.
Cons: Clarity about your role and how you will be measured on your success, although this is impacted by the rapid rate of change. Its important to be clear on your KPI's and make sure that you are leading your own career and managing your manager to help you achieve your outcomes.

PostTitle: Great opportunity to learn, grow and gain exposure to different areas of business.
Pros: Culture due to the people passion and commitment from management actually was believable in most BU's.  A sense of ownership was allowed within certain roles and knowledge that advancement in career did actually occur.
Cons: At times some expectations were unrealistic regarding work/life balance within projects. A lot of talk the talk but did not walk the walk from some managers and staff. Some people played favorites within scope of projects and certain BU's considered themselves more important than others.
Location: Sydney CBD, New South Wales, Australia

PostTitle: Decent salary, good work life balance but poor management.
Pros: Very inclusive & diverse culture. Equal opportunity employer. IT savvy management/executive outlook. A great place to learn modern cutting-edge tools in finance/technology. Collaborative work culture. Good work life balance.
Cons: Poor mid/senior management - don't connect with staff - indifferent to a large extent. No culture of 360 degree feedback. Management often takes hasty decisions without due diligence - fickle minded.

PostTitle: A roller coaster of enjoyable, challenging experiences and long, hard hours.
Pros: Although it was very challenging, my job at CBA gave me a lot of valuable experience. I got a chance to expand my horizons and take on work I hadn't done before. CBA is an employer that looks great on any CV.

Due to problems with the handover of the role to me and subsequent staff shortages, I had to perform my role with insufficient training and inadequate support and consequently I was working long hours. As such, my work-life balance really suffered.

PostTitle: I worked for the bank for many years and the last few years became very stressful and extremely long hours.
Pros: Colleagues, premises
Cons: Sales targets are never adjusted if long term illness or team numbers drop.  Economic changes never factored  the basic wage is low for the job I performed if you didn't make bonus it was low paying for effort.

PostTitle: CBA is an amazing employer that sees potential in people and nurtures personal and professional growth.
Pros: Very professional work place, feel valued as an employee, great incentives, heaps of staff perks and benefits, education and up-skilling, plenty of room and ecouragement to grow.
Cons: Getting everything done that we're expected in the time that we have, tight rostering makes it hard to have holidays when you want, dealing with technology breakdowns constantly.

PostTitle: Hard slog at the start but gets better
One of the best place to work and develop your career.
Pros: Great people in an enjoyable working environment. Many experienced staff and mentors who are approachable and willing to develop your career path. Management team also recognizes your success and ensure you feel valuable and rewarded.
